Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the findings of a study by stating that it shows the death of Alfie Evans was caused by aluminum additives in vaccines, when the study did not mention or allude to any specific medical case, including that of Alfie Evans.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence to support the assertion that aluminum additives in vaccines caused the death of Alfie Evans. The study cited does not provide any direct evidence linking the two, and there is no mention of any medical case involving Alfie Evans in the study.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes a causal relationship between aluminum additives in vaccines and the death of Alfie Evans, without considering other possible factors or medical conditions that may have contributed to his demise.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that Alfie Evans suffered from a rare degenerative brain disease and had been removed from life support after a protracted court battle. There is no evidence to suggest that aluminum poisoning played any role in the development of his condition.
Understate: There is no evidence of any biases that understate the claim.
